content: campfire blanket simple garter stitch stripes make the perfect companion for cozy moments by the fire just add s mores for the ultimate in camping enjoyment by seth richardson campfire blanket v 1 1 05/23 © seth richardson 2020-2023 the design has its origins in the summer of 2020 it was the first summer of the pandemic before vaccines were available and it was just campfire as we were starting to figure out how to socialize outdoors while keeping an appropriate distance at the time i was working at an blanket art museum that had to downsize their staff which meant that my department and my position would be excused for the foreseeable future so i was left with a little extra time on my hands i needed a new project so my friend luigi boccia from brooklyn tweed came to the rescue by dropping off a very large bag of yarn for me work with they were just about to launch their new dapple yarn a lovely mix of cotton and wool and they had a lot of mill ends and partial skeins left over that they couldn t do anything with normally they might have included these in a warehouse sale but the pandemic meant that in-person gatherings like that were still not possible so with this yarn languishing in the corner of their warehouse luigi thought that maybe i could turn it into something new and maybe it would also give me something productive to focus on i wasn t immediately sure what to do with this suddenly large increase in my stash so he suggested that i design a new blanket maybe something that would be a good companion by a fire pit after spending a lot of time untangling the loose ends if you ve ever worked with yarn scraps before you know how much work this can be and then calculating how much yardage i had in each colorway i came up with this striped garter stitch blanket it s my way of playing with color and proportion making something that s almost a rainbow but not quite it s also the first time i started playing with the idea of designing knitting patterns so i sincerely appreciate the encouragement from luigi and the support of brooklyn tweed for setting me out on this new path the photos in this pattern are from that summer of 2020 right after i finished knitting the blanket my mothers-in-law invited us down to southern oregon for a weekend of camping where we could spend some time together outdoors i think it had also been several months since i had a haircut… it ended up being the perfect weekend to give the campfire blanket a test drive since then it has been brought out by many campfires and it works perfectly
